metadata.title: Metal organic frameworks in electrochemical and optical sensing platforms: a review

sections.text: Keywords MOF . CNT . Graphene . Gold nanoparticles . Silver nanoparticles . Copper nanoparticles . Artificial enzymes . Electrochemical sensors . Optical sensors . Composite

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Metal organic frameworks (MOFs), a.k.a. coordination polymers (CPs), can be described as being periodic network structured materials that consist of inorganic building units as connectors and organic linker molecules [1–3] (Fig. 1). In terms of inorganic building units, they contain self-assembly of inorganic metalcontaining nodes i.e., metal ions/clusters. The organic linkers on the other hand, are mostly made up of different configurations
of carboxylates, N-donor groups, and phosphonates. Because of enormous diversity of inorganic nodes and organic linkers and their variable configurations, up to now,more than 20,000MOFs have been reported [4–10].
The synthesis of microporous CPs like Prussian blue, dated back to the eighteenth century. However, MOF synthesis and applications have been known to begin in early 1990s,whichwere pioneered, by Robson, Moore, Yaghi, and Zaworotko [11–17].
In the beginning, due to their advantageous porous and microcrystalline powder structures, they have been used for bulk applications like storage, catalysis and separation. Then, based on their structural flexibility, porosity, and controllable synthesis, MOFs have also been utilized for chemical sensing, heterogeneous catalysis, solid-state material physics and biological applications [1, 2, 18–24].
The other reason that took the usage of MOFs beyond bulk applications, is their better chemical tailorability based on the variety of functional groups on their frameworks. This property also makes MOFs more advantageous compared to other porous materials, like zeolites, active carbon and mesoporous silica. On the other hand, the handicap of fragileness of the
* Ülkü Anik ulkuanik@yahoo.com
* Suna Timur suna.timur@ege.edu.tr
1 Faculty of Science, Chemistry Department, MSKU, 48000 Kotekli, Mugla, Turkey

functional groups in the ligands must be overcome in order to obtain functional MOFs. For this reason, composite MOF structures have been produced by combining MOFs with functional molecules like organic dyes, small bio-molecules, nanomaterials like nanoparticles, nanowires, nanofibers and polymers [11, 25–32]. As a result, better mechanical stability, conductivity, and catalytic performance were obtained with these kinds of composite MOF structures [26, 27]. Up to know, the composite structures like MOF/metal/metal oxide nanoparticles (NPs), MOF/polymers, MOF/enzymes, MOF/ quantum dots (QDs), MOF/polyoxometalates (POMs), MOF/biomolecules, andMOF/carbon nanotubes (CNTs) have been produced and used for different purposes [25, 27].
This review focuses on the usages of MOFs mostly nanomaterial /MOF composites, nanostructured MOFs and enzyme mimicking MOFs in sensing areas. Considering electrochemical sensors/biosensors, MOFs provide important advantages based on electrochemically active metal sites [31–35]. On the other hand, MOFs have also been used in pho to luminescence senso r s s ince they con ta in photoluminescent components which can generate fluorescence like inorganic clusters (especially lanthanides (La)) [31, 36–38] or aromatic or conjugated p moieties included organic linkers [31, 39–41]. In these sensors, generated fluorescence can also be adjusted by the inter-play/interactions
among the building components [1, 42, 43]. For this reason, in terms of sensing, MOFs are very useful for both types of sensors. Combination ofMOFs with suitable nanomaterials or nanostructured metals enhances both the electrochemical and photoluminescence signal depending on the synergetic effects brought by the both sides. In this context, we examined the composite formation of particular nanomaterials with MOFs and used existed studies in the literature in order to support our ideas. A part was also devoted for the usage of artificial enzymatic MOF structure, which have brought a lot of benefit in sensing areas.
Nanomaterial based MOF composites in sensing platforms
Carbon nanomaterial based MOF composites in sensing platforms
Carbon nanomaterials including carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and graphene based nanomaterials are very popular and have been used extensively for many areas [44, 45]. Especially for electrochemical biosensors in order to enhance the electrical conductivity and the mechanical strength, graphen oxide (GO), reduced graphene oxide (rGO) and CNT included
MOF composites have been used [27, 31, 46]. In this context, firstly CNT based MOF composites and then graphene based MOF composites will be examined.
Carbon nanotube/MOF composite based sensors
One of the most popular carbon based nanomaterials, CNTs have three different types of structures namely multiwalled carbon nanotube (MWCNT), single walled carbon nanotube (SWCNT) and double walled carbon nanotube. These three types of CNTs contain a hollow cylindrical sp2-carbon structure with controllable length, diameter, and wall numbers [47, 48]. Owing to unique electrical, thermal, optical and mechanical properties, they have attracted extensive interest and used in many areas [47, 48].
Because of their attractive properties such as crystalline ordered structures, tunable pore sizes, large surface areas, chemical tenability and thermal stability, MOFs have been comprehensively used in sensor and biosensor systems [49]. Considering the electrochemical biosensors, it is claimed that the combination of MOFs with CNTs, improves the conductivity together with electrocatalytical ability [27, 50, 51]. For example, Wang et al., managed to fabricate Ni(II)-basedMOF/MWCNT composites by using in situ solvothermal method for the first time. By this way, they managed to disperse 2–3 nm MOFs nanoparticles onto conducting CNTs which they acted as a current collector through the underlying conducting CNTs. The produced composite was applied for hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) detection. As a result, the sensor showed a wide linear range from 0.01 to 51.6 mmol L−1 and limit of detection (LOD) value of 2.1 mmol L−1. The authors also reported that the developed sensor has very fast response with better stability and conductivity compared to plain MOF included sensors [49].
In another work, a manganese-tyrosine-MWCNT CP, Mn– tyr-MWCNT CP was synthesized hydrothermally and immobilized onto a glassy carbon electrode (GCE). Obtained biosensor demonstrated significant electrocatalytical response to H2O2. It was reported that, the developed biosensor has very good sensitivity of 543 mA mol−1 L cm−2 with linear range of 1.00 × 10−6–1.02 × 10−4 mol L−1, and LOD value of 3.8 × 10−7 mol L−1. In that work, the bidirectional response of the electrode was explained with the presence of Mn, while the electrocatalytic activity was related to the MWCNT usage [52].
There are other MOF/CNT composite included sensing systems rather than electrochemical sensors in the literature. For example, HKUST-1 MOF MWCNT composite thin films were formed via spin coating technique on a quartz-crystal microbalance (QCM) and as a result, a highly sensitive humidity sensor was developed. HKUST-1 is a kind of porous MOF, that contains copper (II) (Cu(II)) paddle wheel building unit interconnected by 1, 3, 5- benzene tricarboxylic acid
linkers. These linkers bring a three dimensional structure with large surface area and open metal sites [48]. Since it can absorb water up to 40 wt%, HKUST-1 is frequently preferred over organics and polymer films for water vapour detection [49]. The composite films were prepared with and without MWCNT and their shift in resonance frequencies to adsorbed water vapor (5–75% relative humidity) was compared (Fig. 2). As a result, with the usage of optimized CNT and HKUST-1 composition, the authors reported 230% increase in sensitivity compared to plain HKUST-1 film with an average sensitivity of about 2.5 × 10–5 (Δf/f) per percent of relative humidity [53]. The CNT/ HKUST-1 structure is demonstrated in Fig. 2. The other MOF/CNT based sensors were summarized in Table 1.
Graphene/MOF composite based sensors/biosensors
Graphene is another popular carbon based nanomaterial which was discovered in 2004 by Geim and Novoselov. Besides many advantages, it has high conductivity and electrocatalytic activity. Graphene’s sp2 hybridized two dimensional sheets provide high surface area together with ease in the decoration of this material with suitable metallic

nanomaterials. Also, it has been claimed that these sheets are the reasons for effective electron transfer at the edges. For these reasons, graphene and graphene based nanomaterials like GO have been widely utilized for electroanalytical purposes [44, 64, 65].
ConsideringMOF/graphene- based composites, it has been demonstrated that, the electron transfer rate is increased since graphene acts like conductive bridges in the graphene/MOF composite [66]. For these reasons, there are many works in the literature that concern the usage of different MOF/graphene based nanomaterial composites in electrochemical sensors/ biosensors [66]. For instance, graphene nanoribbons (GNRs) were used as a substrate where nanocrystals of a porphyrinic metal–organic framework, MOF-525 was growth solvothermally. As a result, a nanocomposite which included MOF-525 nanocrystals interconnected one-dimensional GNRs was prepared. This MOF-525/GNR nanocomposite thin film was formed homogenously onto conducting glass substrates and obtained system was used as electrochemical
nitrite sensors. The MOF-525 nanocrystals provided high surface area while the interconnected GNRs pretended to be conductive bridges that fastened the electron transfer. As a result, more effective and robust sensor was fabricated for monitoring the oxidation of nitrite compared to the pristine MOF-525 thin film [66].
Sometimes, graphene based nanomaterials are combined both with suitable metals and MOF structure. As a result, very effective composites were obtained. For instance, Asadian et al., managed to synthesize nickelcopper (NiCo) layered double hydroxide (LDH) nanosheets/ GNRs that was put on GCE and used for non-enzymatic glucose detection (Fig. 3). The fabrication procedure was made up of two stages. In the first stage, ZIF-67 dodecahedron nanocrystals (MOF) were used as sacrificial template for the growth nanoflower-like NiCo LDH nanosheets. Then, in order to obtain mechanically robust modified electrode, the fabricated nanosheets were mixed with GNRs which were prepared via longitudinal unzipping of MWCNTs. Amperometric and cyclic
Fig.3 A carbon nanomaterial/MOF composite based sensor: Schematic illustration of the GCE modification procedure with NiCo nanosheets/ GNRs composite: (a) Synthesis of NiCo LDHNSs from ZIF-67 template
and (b) preparation of narrow graphene nanoribbons via Longitudinal unzipping of MWCNT. Reprinted with permission from ref. [67]. Copyright 2018 from Elsevier
voltammetric (CV) techniques were used for the examination of developed electrode’s performance towards the glucose sensing. As a result, fast and sensitive (344 μAmM− 1 cm− 2) sensor with a LOD value of 0.6 μM and linear range of 5 μM to 0.8 mM was obtained. Besides these, it has been found that NiCo nanosheetss/GNR electrode had long-term stability with good selectivity towards the analytes like ascorbic acid, uric acid and dopamine [67]. The preparation of this sensor is presented in Fig. 3. The other applications of graphene/MOF composite can be seen in Table 1.
From the examples above, it is obvious that combination of MOF with carbon based nanomaterials provides important benefits like enhanced conductivity, higher surface area and robust structure. Especially in the case of electrochemical sensing platforms, these properties increases the developed system performance in terms of sensitivity and stability.
Metal/metal oxide/MOF composite based sensors/biosensors
Asmentioned before, introduction of nanomaterials in sensing systems provide significant enhance in signals depending on the transducers that it has been used. For example, in electrochemical sensors/biosensors, the nanomaterials including metal/metal oxide nanomaterials offer better conductivity, higher surface area and good biocompatibility [68]. Also depending on the spectroscopic properties of utilized metallic nanoparticles, metallic nanoparticle/MOF composites can also be versatile to be used in spectroscopic sensing systems like fluorescence sensors [69]. Recently, MOFs have been introduced to these systems and used as pre-concentrators, molecular filters and templates in a way of mesoporous silica or
zeolites. On the other hand, MOFs differ from the latter two since with MOFs, it is possible to adjust the pore size and chemistry and by this way, the sensitivity is increased since the amount of adsorbed molecules is increased [69, 70].

sections.heading: Gold nanoparticle/MOF composites
sections.text:
Gold nanoparticle (AuNp) is one of the most popular metallic nanomaterial that has been used in sensor applications. Besides its enhanced electronic properties and higher surface area, AuNP has also a biocompatible structure which is very important for the biosensor applications [68, 71].
Considering AuNP MOF combination, for sensor and biosensor applications, usually AuNP was used as a modifier for other metallic based MOF structure [72, 73]. An example of AuNP/MOF composite is demonstrated in Fig. 4.
Wang et al., synthesized AuNP modified Cu-MOFs and used it for sensitive detection of microRNA (miRNA). It was reported that the synthesis of Cu-MOFs not only increased the catalytic effect but also brought larger surface area for AuNPs enveloping and DNA strand 1 (S1) immobilization. During the measurements, the released target started many of cycles, and the constructed S1-AuNPs@Cu-MOFs nanocomposite was attached to the modified electrode via chain hybridization. It was believed that this chain hybridization has effect on signal amplification. In terms of analytical characteristics, the researchers have found out that the linear range of developed electrode was in the range of 1.0 fM to 10 nM with LOD value of 0.35 fM for miRNA-155. According to authors, this higher sensitivity and wide linear range were due to the catalytic effects that came from AuNPs and Cu-MOFs towards the glucose. [72].
Fig.4. A clear illustration of metallic NP/MOF structure: TEM images of Au-NP/MOF composites: a ZnO NRs, b ZnO NRs@Au and (c,d) ZnO NRs@Au@ZIF-8 composites with Au NPs at different locations: c inside and (d) near to the surface of ZIF-8. Scale bar, 100 nm. Reproduced from [74]
Besides electrochemical sensing systems, fluorescent sensors have also been fabricated based on AuNP/MOF nanocomposites. Apart from the organic dye molecules and inorganic quantum dots, MOFs have also been used frequently in these sensor structures [75, 76]. Porous structure, higher specific surface and tunable properties ofMOFs, allow them to be used extensively in these systems [40, 75]. On the contrary, MOFs can be affected easily from the interferences created by the external factors in the analysis. In order to avoid these types of fluctuations and improve the accuracy of the fluorometric measurements, in some fluorometric procedures, reference fluorescence signals were used [75, 77]. This process is called ratiometric fluorescence analysis and has been used extensively for biological and environmental assays [78–81]. As an example to this process, a practical and effective ratiometric fluorescent nanosensor based on BSA– AuNPs@Tb–AMP (BSA, bovine serum albumin; AMP, adenosine 5′-monophosphate; Tb, terbium) MOF nanostructures had been produced by encapsulating BSA–AuNPs into Tb–AMP MOFs. The prepared fluorescent sensor was used for the detection of 2,6-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (DPA) and Hg(II) ions. The measurement was based on the enhancement of fluorescence of Tb–AMPMOFs due to the coordination of DPAwith Tb (III) which resulted with the replacement of the water molecules from the Tb (III) center. It has been reported that during this enhancement, the fluorescence of BSA– AuNPs at 405 nm remained constant. Meanwhile, when Hg(II) was added to the medium, the fluorescence of BSA– AuNPs at 635 nm was quenched but the fluorescence of Tb– AMP MOFs remained constant. After the investigation of analytical characteristics, it has been found that DPA linear range was between 50 nM to 10 μM with LOD value of 17.4 nM. For Hg(II), the linear range was from 50 nM to 1 μM with LOD value of 20.9 nM. Lastly developed sensor was applied for DPA and Hg2+ detection in running water and very promising results were obtained [75].
It has been known that, metallic nanomaterials/MOF composite that are used in sensor systems are generally prepared by placing these nanomaterials into MOF structures [69]. Also, the working principle is based on the measurement of interaction of analyte molecule with metallic nanomaterials, which diffuses through the MOF pores and reaches them [69]. For this reason, the properties of the MOFs directly affect the performance of the sensor [69, 82]. For instance, Sugikawa et al . prepared a MOF-5 suppor ted Au nanorod (AuNR@MOF-5) sensor which produced Surface-Enhanced Raman Scattering signals when interacted with particular pyridine derivatives [82]. The group claims that produced AuNR@MOF-5 size can be adjusted via concentration of AuNR. Also, they proved that only small the pyridine derivatives diffused through nanopores of MOF-5 shells and interacted with the surface of AuNR which embedded in
MOF-5 nanocrystals [83]. The other type of AuNP/MOF composites can be seen in Table 2.

sections.heading: Silver nanoparticle/MOF composites
sections.text:
Silver nanoparticles (AgNP) attract many attentions because of their important features like enhanced electrical conductivity, improved photoelectrochemical activity together with antimicrobial activity [101–105]. In the MOFs composites, AgNPs combine these advantages with the MOFs conveniences.
Bagheri et al., prepared Ag nanoparticle/flake-like zinc (Zn)-based MOF nanocomposite (AgNPs@ZnMOF) which has enhanced peroxidase-like activity and they used this nanocomposite as a support for molecularly imprinted polymer (MIP). The developed system was utilized for the fluorimetric detection of patulin. The fabrication procedure of AgNPs@ZnMOF was based on producing AgNPs inside the nano-pores of flake-like (Zn)MOF. Considering the structural higher surface area of MOF, it is obvious that the catalytic activity of Ag NPs was increased. Also, in order to increase the selectivity, MIP layer was fabricated on the surface of AgNPs@ZnMOF by co-polymerization reaction of 3- aminopropyl triethoxysilane (APTES) and tetraethyl orthosilicate monomers, and patulin was utilized as template agent. The measurement principle relied on the catalysis of obtained MIP-capped AgNPs@ZnMOF to H2O2-terephthalic acid reaction which produced a high florescent product. As a result, it was found that the fluorescence intensity was decreased proportional to patulin concentration in the range of 0.1–10 μmol L−1 with LOD of 0.06 μmol L−1 [106].
Usually, it is possible to load metallic nanoparticles into porous and flexible MOFs cages/channels which result with the metal@MOF composites [107, 108]. In this formation, MOFs are the supporters which encapsulate the metal nanoparticles while the planted metal nanoparticles can uniformly spread in the internal framework of MOFs. Meanwhile, based on the pore size of MOFs, usually nanosized metal particles were produced in the MOFs [95, 107, 109].
Meng et al. modified GCE with AgNP included cobalt (Co)-based MOF, Ag@ZIF-67 nanocomposite and used it as an electrochemical sensor for glucose detection. The ZIF-67 modified GCE showed an excellent catalytic activity towards glucose oxidation. In order to obtain Ag@ZIF-67 nanocomposite, a sequential deposition-reduction method was applied. After the investigation of effect of Ag loadings onto the sensor performance, the analytical characteristics were examined. The linear range about glucose was found between range of 2–1000μM,with a high sensitivity of 0.379 μAμM −1 cm −2 and LOD value of limit of 0.66 μM [107]. The other selected similar works can be seen in Table 2.

Copper and/or copper oxide nanostructures/ MOF composite
Copper nanoparticles (CuNPs) have been extensively used for non-enzymatic glucose sensors since they provide better analytical characteristics like wider linear range etc. [110–119].
In one study, self-supported CuO/Cu2O@CuO/Cu2O core– shell nanowire arrays (NWAs) were prepared wherein then anodized Cu(OH)2 NWAs converted to HKUST-1 at room temperature (Fig. 5). As it is stated, calcination procedure turned Cu(OH)2 NWAs cores and HKUST-1 shells into CuO/Cu2O successively and CuO/Cu2 O@CuO/Cu 2O core–shell NWAs was produced. By this way, the agglomeration of MOF-derived materials in particle-shape was avoided while the ion diffusion and the active sites were enhanced. Obtained smart structure was used directly as the working electrode and applied for the non-enzymatic glucose detection. Examined analytical characteristics of this sensor stated that on CuO/Cu2O@CuO/Cu2O core–shell NWAs had the sensitivity of 10.090 μA mM −1 cm −2 with LOD value of 0.48 μM and linear range of 0.99–1.330 μM. Also the selectivity studies of this glucose sensor towards uric acid, ascorbic acid (AA) and L-Cysteine demonstrated that developed sensor had remarkable selectivity to these analytes [110]. This interesting MOF structure and preparation of concerned sensor are given in Fig. 5.
There are also works in the literature where Cu is combined with another metal to form a bimetallic catalyst in the MOF. For example, the usage of Ni nanocrystals in glucose sensors provides high sensitivity, low detection limit, and enhanced stability [117, 120, 121]. On the contrary, Ni catalysts based glucose sensors show narrow linearity which badly influence the applicability of the developed sensor [121]. In order to solve this, a self-supported CuNi/C electrode fabricated by electrodepositing Cu nanoparticles on a Ni-based MOF derivate and obtained electrode was utilized as a non-enzymatic glucose sensor. Because of the porosity and carbon platform, enhanced kinetic properties were observed. As a result, constructed CuNi/C electrode showed a high sensitivity of 17.12 mA mM−1 cm−2, a low detection limit of 66.67 nM, and a wider linearity range from 0.20 to 2.72 mM. The electrode was also applied for the glucose detection in human blood serum samples and very promising results were obtained [111].
The similar explanation can again be used for the usage of metallic-nanostructures/MOF structure in sensing systems. In the case of electrochemical sensors, as metallic NP provides enhanced electrocatalytic activity, MOF structure gives higher surface area which allows presence of more metallic-NP. As a result, more sensitive systems were obtained. For optical sensors, porous structure and tunable properties of MOFs make them preferable. Especially the flexibility of MOF structures
allow them to be modified easily and accommodate more effective results for these sensors.
Other MOF or metal/metal oxide/MOF nanostructures in sensing platforms
Apart from Au, Ag and Cu based metal/MOF structures, the other metallic/MOF nanostructures will be discussed in this section. Also more metal and /or metal oxide MOF composites applications are listed in Table 2.
In another work, a nanoporous carbon/cobalt oxide (NPC/ Co3O4) composite was synthesized from a single-precursor (zeolitic imidazolate framework-67) and applied for AA detection. It has been reported that direct carbonization of MOFs leads to the synthesis of porous carbon materials with extremely high surface areas together with homogenous poresize distributions. Insight of these properties, as it is expected, developed composite displayed very sensitive, selective and reproducible results for AA, linearity in the 2–240 mM AA, with a 20 nM detection limit [122].
As mentioned before, due to the MOF structure, many advantages are offered for the usage of these materials in sensing and biosensing areas. For example, due to their variable coordination geometries, multiemission, and high structure stability, La (III)-based MOFs are good candidates to produce effective results in these areas. Abdelhamid et al., manage to prepare water stable and porous La-MOF nanoparticles where the tritopic linker of 2,4,6-tri-p-carboxyphenyl pyridine (H3L2) and La(III) were used as metal clusters. In this MOF, La—O chains were formed by using H3L2 linkers as connector. As a result, this MOF had large 1D channels (11.3 Å) where small molecules can easily be attached. Resulting MOF also had high fluorescence emission between pH 6 to 12. By measuring the selective quenching that was caused by Fe(III) ions, a linear range of 16.6–167μMwith LOD value of 16.6 μM for Fe(III) ions were obtained. Also developed sensing probe was applied detection of tryptophan among some others amino acids. Since only L-tryptophan quenched the fluorescence emmison of MOF’s while the other amino acids increasing it, selective detection of this amino acid had been achieved [123].
The other sensing system including MOF, was developed for the photoelectrochemical detection of herbicide clethodim. For this purpose, an amino-functionalizedMOF was modified with titanium dioxide (TiO2) and as a result, amino-MIL (Materials from Institute Lavoisier)-125/TiO2 MOF was obtained. After that, developed MOF was attached onto a GCE electrode and photoelectrocatalytic activity that was produced by resulting electrode was monitored. For generating the photocurrent, electrons were produced via the illumination of amino-MIL-125/TiO2 by visible light. After the excitement of these electrons, they transferred to GCE, creating positively
charged holes (h+) on the surface of the amino-MIL-125/ TiO2. Then hydroxy radicals (•OH) were produced by means of reaction of these holes with H2O. Generated •OHs were caught by clethodim and as a result, an enhanced photocurrent was occurred. Under the optimized working conditions, the linear range was in between 0.2 to 25 μmol L−1, while LOD was found 10 nmol L−1 [124].
Palladium (Pd) nanoparticles were combined with an amino-functionalized MOF (NH2-MIL-101(Cr)) and used for electrochemical nitrite detection. The modification of screen printed electrode was made just by dropping Pd/NH2MIL-101(Cr)onto the electrode surface. Various voltammetric techniques including CV, linear sweep voltammetry, and square wave voltammetry were used to study electrochemical signal of nitrite. After the optimization of experimental parameters, the linear range was found between 5 to 150 nM nitrite concentration range, with the detection limit of 1.3 nM. The developed electrochemical sensor was applied for the nitrite determination in in sausage and pickle samples via standard additionmethod. As it is reported, very promising results were obtained [125].
In another interesting MIL-101 included sensor has been constructed by introducing MIL-101with fluorescein-labeled DNA probes, exonuclease of type RecJf, and targets. The developed sensor was applied for thrombin and oxytetracycline detection. It was reported that LOD values were found as 15 pM and 4.2 nM for thrombin and for oxytetracycline respectively. The authors explained obtained better selectivity with the existence of MIL-101 protected aptamers and high sensitivity with the signal amplification exerted by the exonuclease-assisted target-recycling [126].
MOF structures as artificial enzymes in sensing platforms
Artificial enzymes are very popular in the research field because they can be easily produced and purified with good stability. Also they can be used many times without needing to be prepared frequently. Based on the structure included metal type, MOFs show artificial enzyme properties which are very useful for sensor and biosensor applications [127–129]. For example, iron(Fe)-based MOFs have been proven to have peroxidase-like catalytic activity and are used for colorimetric detection H2O2, glucose, thrombin, AA, and thiol [130, 131]. Insight of these researches, a bimetallicMOF, that made up ofMOF(Co/2Fe) was synthesized via hydrothermal method. ThisMOF structure showed dual enzymemimetic activities, peroxidase-like activity and oxidase-like activity, and utilized for colorimetric detection of H2O2. The working principle relied on the catalytic activation of prepared MOF which is dependent onmedium’s temperature and pH, towards the oxidation of 3,3,5,5-tetramethylbenzidine (TMB) to
produce a blue product both in the absence and presence of H2O2. After the optimization of experimental parameters, the linear range was found between 10 to 100 μM H2O2 with a 5 μM LOD value [130].
In a similar work, where Fe based MOF (Fe-MIL-101) was acted as a peroxidase mimic, was implemented in the microfluidic paper-based analytical devices (μPAD) system [132]. As it is well known, microfluidics provides many advantages including simplicity and compatibility together with portability in analysis. Recently paper has been used in these systems as an attractive substrate material and is accepted as an innovative platform technology due to its flexibility, lightness, low thickness and inexpensive nature. As a result, μPADS have been produced [133].
The developed device which detection system contained a digital camera and the iOS feature of a smartphone, was used for glucose detection. The working principle was based on the formation of H2O2 via glucose oxidase on glucose and then the MOF causes the oxidation of TMB by H2O2 to form a blue-green product that had an absorption peak at 650 nm. Under the optimal working conditions, the detection limit was estimated as 2.5 μmol·L−1 with the μPAD stability of 21 days. [132]. The reason that Fe-MIL-101 was used in this study was explained in terms of this MOF’s catalytic effects. Fe-MIL-101 is a zeolite type MOF that contains rigid terephthalate ligands. Since it contains terminal water molecules, it is easy to create unsaturated coordination sites just by applying heat to the structure [134, 135].
Enzyme mimicking property of these MOF structures is important in the case of biosensors. Especially for the bienzymatic systems, elimination of one enzyme makes the specific biosensor reaction less complicated. Also introducing NP/MOF structure instead of second enzyme will bring sensitivity and practicality for the developed biosensor system.

sections.heading: Conclusions and future perspectives
sections.text:
There is no doubt that composite formation extends the spectrum of the application areas of MOFs. Especially the combination of MOFs with suitable nanomaterials usually results with robust and effective composite structures. The variety and correspondence of nanomaterials allow them to be used in many areas including different types of sensing systems. In electrochemical sensors, nanomaterial/MOF composites increase the electrical conductivity hence sensitivity of the measurements. Also, since the surface area is increased based on the MOF utilization, the catalytic effect that is provided by nanomaterials is increased. Moreover, with the adjustment of pore size, only particular analytes are allowed to diffuse into MOF which in turn enhance the selectivity of the procedure. However, some points must be taken into account during the preparation of these composites. One of them is the
distraction of the MOF structures. As providers of enhanced properties, produced MOFs must have high surface area, sequential network structure and porous structure. For this reason, necessary precautions must be taken during the characterization studies of resulted MOF composites. Lastly we believe that, the application areas together with numbers of MOF/nanomaterial composites will be increased in future, which provides more optimized and stable composite structures.

metadata.abstractText: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are porous coordination polymers (CP) produced by metal-based nodes and multitopic organic ligands. Based on their porous and microcrystalline powder structures, they have initially been used for storage, catalysis and separation. Then, because of their advantageous properties like ease of the tailoring, they also have been applied in areas like chemical sensing, biological applications, etc. The CPs were combined with molecules such as organic dyes, small biomolecules, nanomaterials like nanoparticles, nanowires, nanofibers and polymers and as a result, composite MOFs have been produced. By this way, better mechanical stability, conductivity, and catalytic performance were obtained. This review (with 135 refs.) summarizes the progress made in the past years in the field of electrochemical and optical sensing based on the use of MOFs. Following an introduction into the field, large sections cover MOF based sensors exploiting (a) carbon nanomaterials (with subsections on carbon nanotubes, graphene and its derivatives), (b) metal/metal oxide MOFs; including gold, silver, copper and/ or copper oxide nanoparticle and other metal/MOF composites. Enzyme mimicking MOFs are discussed next. In this context, after the brief information about focused MOFs, the nanomaterial/MOF composites were discussed and related examples were presented.
